Subclassing & Multiclassing

Character specialization and class combination systems

Subclasses

Every class has subclasses—specialized paths that define how you approach your class's core themes.

Gaining a Subclass

  • Choose a subclass at 3rd level (or 1st level for Clerics and Sorcerers)
  • Once chosen, you typically cannot change your subclass
  • Gain subclass features at specific levels (varies by class)

Subclass Progression

ClassSubclass LevelFeature Levels
Cleric, Sorcerer11, 6, 17
Druid, Wizard22, 6, 10, 14
Most Others33, 7, 10, 15, 18

Multiclassing

Instead of gaining levels in a single class, you can take levels in multiple classes.

Prerequisites

To multiclass into or out of a class, you must have at least 13 in the class's primary ability:

ClassAbility Requirement
BarbarianStrength 13
BardCharisma 13
ClericWisdom 13
DruidWisdom 13
FighterStrength 13 or Dexterity 13
MonkDexterity 13 and Wisdom 13
PaladinStrength 13 and Charisma 13
RangerDexterity 13 and Wisdom 13
RogueDexterity 13
SorcererCharisma 13
WarlockCharisma 13
WizardIntelligence 13

Experience Points

  • Your character level is the total of all class levels
  • XP requirements are based on character level, not individual class levels

Hit Points and Hit Dice

  • Add together Hit Dice from all classes
  • Hit points when gaining a level: Roll or take average of new class's Hit Die + CON

Proficiency Bonus

  • Based on total character level (not individual class levels)
  • You don't gain all proficiencies from multiclassing—see Multiclassing Proficiencies table

Proficiencies Gained

When multiclassing, you gain only some of a class's starting proficiencies:

ClassProficiencies Gained
BarbarianShields, simple weapons, martial weapons
BardLight armor, one skill, one musical instrument
ClericLight armor, medium armor, shields
DruidLight armor, medium armor, shields
FighterLight armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons
MonkSimple weapons, shortswords
PaladinLight armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons
RangerLight armor, medium armor, shields, simple weapons, martial weapons, one skill
RogueLight armor, one skill, thieves' tools
SorcererNone
WarlockLight armor, simple weapons
WizardNone

Class Features

  • You gain class features from all your classes
  • Channel Divinity: If multiclassing with Cleric/Paladin, uses combine
  • Extra Attack: Does not stack; having it from multiple classes doesn't give additional attacks
  • Unarmored Defense: Choose which version to use if you have multiple

Spellcasting (Multiclass)

Spell Slots: Combine levels from all spellcasting classes:

  • Full casters (Bard, Cleric, Druid, Sorcerer, Wizard): Count full class level
  • Half casters (Paladin, Ranger): Count half class level (rounded down)
  • Third casters (Eldritch Knight, Arcane Trickster): Count one-third class level (rounded down)
  • Warlock: Uses Pact Magic separately; doesn't combine with other spellcasting

Spells Known and Prepared:

  • Determined individually for each class
  • Can cast any spell you know/prepare using any available spell slot of appropriate level

Important Notes

  • Multiclassing is an optional rule—check with your DM
  • Can be complex; understand each class's features before multiclassing
  • May delay or prevent access to high-level class features
